column1: Rancho Cordova is a city in Sacramento County
column2: California
column3: United States which was incorporated in 2003. It is part of the Sacramento Metropolitan Area. The population was 64
column4: 776 at the 2010 census. Rancho Cordova is the Sacramento area's largest employment sub-center
column5: attracting over 50
column6: 000 commuters. The city is served by Sacramento Regional Transit's various bus lines and the Gold Line light rail line
column7: though fewer than 0.1 percent of commuters to Rancho Cordova use the line according to the US Census Bureau's American Community Survey (2010-2012). In 2010 and 2019 Rancho Cordova was named as a winner of the All-America City Award.

column1: Originally called Mayhew's Crossing and Hangtown Crossing (c. 1855) during the Gold Rush era
column2: the area was renamed Mayhew Station and Mills Station (c. 1900)
column3: respectively. The city itself was named for the Cordova Vineyard
column4: which was located in the center of the Rancho Rio de los Americanos land grant. Other names of the town included Cordova Vineyards and Cordova Village
column5: before it was officially named Rancho Cordova when a post office was established in the community in 1955.In the Gold Rush era of mid 19th century California
column6: certain Placer mining activities took place in the Rancho Cordova environs
column7: some traces of which disturbance are extant. The elevation of the generally level terrain is approximately 118 feet (36 m) above mean sea level. Lone Star Gravel Company and other companies have historically extracted younger gravels at depths of 30 to 40 feet (12 m) without encountering groundwater
column8: which is characteristically found at about 100 feet (30 m). Partially confined groundwater generally flows to the southwest.For many years
column9: Rancho Cordova was the community called ‘Mills’
column10: located in the eastern part of the Brighton Township. It was called Mills as early as 1893
column11: supposedly because of the old grist mills that were close by along the river. At the top of Bradshaw
column13: close to the oak tree that marked the northwest boundary of the Spanish Land Grant
column15: there are still some remains of foundations. You can locate them by looking for the Grist Mill Dam Recreation Area along the American River Parkway. The southwestern boundary of the grant was 300 feet west of Bradshaw not far north of Florin Road. The boundary then went due east over to Grantline Road

column2: 500 acre Rancho Rio De Los Americanos was granted to William Leidesdorff in 1844 but he died in 1848
column3: leaving the Rancho and some properties in San Francisco to his heirs. Capt. Joseph Folsom purchased the Rancho from the heirs and founded a town in 1855 which he named after himself – Folsom. The old Liedesdorff adobe was constructed in 1846 in the vicinity of Routier Station.

Joseph Routier was widely renowned for many years for the quality of his produce. In 1866 the railroad built the train station between Folsom Boulevard and the tracks due to the size and dependability of the crop
column8: and the need for a formal packing shed to house the produce waiting for the train. (The station still exists as Pfingst Realty Mr. Pfingst died in 2007; the structure is owned by his daughter.)

column2: the road forked. The Coloma Road went north along the river to Coloma and the northern mines
column3: very close to its present location; the southerly fork headed for White Rock and the southern mines. The area was first known as Hangtown Crossing
column4: referencing the route to Old Hangtown – or Placerville. The southerly fork was the White Rock Road
column5: known at that time as the White Rock – Clarksville Immigrant Road. The outcropping of white rock marked the entry into El Dorado County
column6: and Clarksville was the first sizable settlement over the hill. 15 Mile House was built in 1850
column7: and is commemorated with a brick cairn on White Rock Road in front of the CalTrans Emergency Ops building. It was managed by A.M. Plummer until purchased in 1857 by its most famous innkeeper
column8: H.F.W. Deterding. His son Charles ran the hotel until at least 1890
column9: and their hospitality was known far and wide. 15 Mile House was the second official Pony Express remount station. Eleven miles east of that

column11: before the express riders went over the mountains headed for St. Joseph
column12: Missouri. The Mormon Island ruins surface from under Folsom Lake at Dike 8 during low water years.

column1: The agricultural heritage of Rancho Cordova fell onto hard times in the 1930s and 1940s. Along with Joseph Routier's nationally recognized produce
column2: wine from Roland Federspiel's Cordova Vineyards had been served at White House table during the Teddy Roosevelt presidency. Unfortunately
column3: northern California went through a lengthy period of drought. Making things worse
column4: the State Legislature raised property tax rates
column5: setting values at "the highest and best use" as opposed to the actual use of the land. It became more and more difficult for farmers to keep their land in production.

column2: all of the young men returning from World War II were looking for places to settle down
column3: find a job
column4: buy a home
column5: and raise their families. Roland Federspiel formed a partnership with Glenn Ahlstrom and a contractor named Jacobsen to build homes on land that had previously been vineyards. Up until that point after the War
column6: there had not been any production housing in the United States. Homes had been constructed individually or in small numbers.

column1: Construction began at the intersection of Folsom Boulevard and Zinfandel Drive. The first three homes on the west side of the street were the model homes. Duplexes on the opposite corners originally housed the sales office and post office
column2: then the first office of The Grapevine newspaper. There was a playground for children whose parents were touring the model homes
column3: and Art Linkletter came to cut the ribbon at the Grand Opening!

column1: Federspiel had chosen the name Cordova Vineyards with a nod to the Cordoba Region in Spain
column2: and wanted to preserve the Cordova name. Glenn Ahlstrom drove down to San Francisco in his old woodie station wagon and physically brought back the first ‘post box’. The US Postal Service agreed to let them use the name Rancho Cordova as it was just the right size to fit around the circle of the old postal franking stamp. They named the streets for wine grapes. It is a treat to find some of those old grapes coming back into production again
column3: with wines like Malbec and Barbera. In recognition of that heritage
column4: Elliott Homes named all of the streets in the Villages of Zinfandel at Stonecreek for wineries around the world when they began to build at the south end of Zinfandel in 2000.

column2: and Folsom Boulevard began to fill in with commercial enterprise.  Early structures included the Cordova Village Shopping Center and George E. Johnson's Cordova Inn. (George E. Johnson is the father of restaurateur Eppie Johnson. The ‘E’ stands for Eppaminondous
column3: and Eppie used it to name a more formal restaurant on Zinfandel around 1980. The building is still in operation as a restaurant today
column4: but is on the fourth restaurant chain since then.)

column1: Most of the residents of the 1950s and 1960s came to work at either Aerojet
column2: during the height of the space race
column3: or were stationed at Mather Air Force Base. There were only a little over 1
column4: 000 homes in the Mather housing area
column5: so most people lived off base. Along with other people who found the new Rancho Cordova a desirable place to live were the many people who came to open businesses and establish all of the organizations that any true community needs in order to thrive and prosper. Early residents opened gas stations

column1: They invented a new organization called the Cordova Community Council as a means for all of these civic institutions to come together to share information and work on community projects. One of the first efforts literally resulted in putting Rancho Cordova on the map! It bothered everyone that Rancho Cordova did not appear on the Rand McNally's
column2: and they wrote letters persistently until the mapping company gave up and put Rancho Cordova on the map.

column1: There were attempts to incorporate Rancho Cordova in 1961 and in 1978. The 1978 effort was kept alive over the next 20 years
column2: and finally got to the ballot in November 2002. It passed with a record 77% of voters in support
column3: a record that still stands today.
Emery Worldwide Flight 17 crashed in Rancho Cordova. All three crew members
column4: the only occupants of the aircraft
column5: were killed.

column1: Following the adoption of the 1978 Cordova Community Plan
column2: the Sacramento County Local Agency Formation Commission adopted a sphere of influence for Rancho Cordova.  This is one of the defining documents of the actual community boundary for the community.

The City of Rancho Cordova has a council-manager form of government with five members elected to the council
column2: one of whom serves as mayor each year. The mayor's post is thus simply that of "chief among equals for a time". As of 2016
column3: Rancho Cordova's mayor is Donald Terry
column4: and Linda Budge is vice mayor. All current City Council members have served as mayor during their terms on the council.

column1: The City of Rancho Cordova has maintained nine straight years of balanced budgets. Its sound financial status has been recognized by the rating agency Standard and Poor. In July 2012 Standard and Poor's (S&P) Rating Services reaffirmed the City of Rancho Cordova's A+ long-term rating
column2: noting the City's outlook is stable and its financial performance has been good. As a credit-rating agency
column3: S&P issues credit ratings for the debt of public and private corporations and has been designated a nationally recognized statistical rating organization by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. According to S&P
column4: Rancho Cordova's rating reflects the city's "very strong wealth indicator
column5: its good financial performance leading to a very strong fund balance
column6: good financial management practices and policies
column7: and its access to Eastern Sacramento metropolitan area." "In our opinion
column8: Rancho Cordova's financial performance has been good with the City historically reporting consecutive surpluses
column9: said S&P's analysis report.  The stable outlook reflects our view that City officials will likely continue to make the budgetary adjustments needed to maintain balanced operations
column10: supported by at least what we consider strong available fund reserves."

column1: Rancho Cordova students are served by four school districts
column2: with the majority of schools in the Folsom-Cordova Unified School District and has three high schools: Cordova High School
column3: Walnutwood High School
column4: and Kinney High School. Two elementary schools and one high school in the Sacramento Unified School District serve students in the western portion of Rancho Cordova
column5: and students in the recently developed Anatolia area are served by Elk Grove Unified School District. A small number of students attend schools in the San Juan Unified School District.

column1: Data on the educational status of Rancho Cordovans shows that approximately 85% of residents 25 years or older have a high school education and 22% of residents hold some type of college or post-secondary school degree. In Sacramento County
column2: 85% of residents 25 years or older have a high school education and 28% of residents hold some type of college or post-secondary school degree. In California
column3: 80% of residents 25 years or older have a high school education and 30% of residents hold some type of college or post-secondary school degree.

column1: The city is served by three water agencies and one sewage treatment agency.Electricity is provided by SMUD and natural gas is provided by Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

column2: Rancho Cordova has maintained a law enforcement services contract with the Sacramento County Sheriff's Department. While deputies assigned to Rancho Cordova wear unique "Rancho Cordova" uniform patches and drive police vehicles with "Rancho Cordova" markings
column3: they are
column4: in fact
column5: sheriff's deputies. The structure of the contracted Rancho Cordova Police Department closely mirrors that of an independent police department and includes detectives
column6: traffic enforcement
column7: community service officers
column9: and administration functions. Per the contract
column10: the City of Rancho Cordova pays the salaries for 55 sworn and 7 non-sworn staff. This arrangement for contracted law enforcement services is fairly common among California cities because it requires fewer overhead costs than running an independent police department and allows the city to avoid long-term pension obligations for police employees.Sacramento Metropolitan Fire District provides fire/EMS services.
